channel.title: +Syed Ahmed on hindu-vichArAH हिन्दु-विचाराः

item.title: 116 UNKNOWN_TITLE
item.description: Source: Sir Syed Ahmed on the Present State of Indian Politics, Consisting of Speeches and Letters Reprinted from the “Pioneer” (Allahabad: The Pioneer Press, 1888), pp. 1-24. Modern facsimile version (Lahore: Sang-e-Meel Publications, 1982). Translator unknown. The text presented here has been slightly edited for classroom use, and its punctuation slightly improved, by FWP. Paragraph numbers, and some paragraph breaks, and annotations in square brackets have been added by FWP. The original spellings have been retained; all the footnotes are original.

*BACK TO THE PIONEER’S TRANSLATION WITHOUT FWP’S VERSION* SPEECH OF SIR SAYYID AHMAD KHAN AT LUCKNOW, 1887 [TABLE] NOTES /1/ Men of position and influence. /2/ A Congress recently held in Lucknow for the discussion of Mahomedan education. /3/ Landlord. /4/ Tenant. – back to Sir Sayyid’s speech, Lucknow, 1887 – more on Sir Sayyid – Glossary – fwp’s main page –

[TABLE] NOTES /5/ Tailors. /6/ The National Congress was then sitting at Madras. /7/ A very low caste. /8/ Common Bengali names. – back to Sir Sayyid’s speech, Lucknow, 1887 – more on Sir Sayyid – Glossary – fwp’s main page –
[TABLE] NOTES /9/ Be off to Madras. /10/ Scoundrels. – back to Sir Sayyid’s speech, Lucknow, 1887 – more on Sir Sayyid – Glossary – fwp’s main page –

[TABLE] NOTE in the Urdu edition: “Sir Sayyid gave this lecture orally; there were no notes or memoranda in Sir Sayyid’s hands concerning the lecture. Thus he went on speaking with extreme fluency. So that this valuable, important, and historical lecture [[28]] would have been lost, if Munshi ‘Aziz ud-Din Ahmad, Tahsildar of Mirzapur, with extreme swiftness and dexterity had not written along with him as he was speaking. Munshi Sahib took great care, and having written out the lecture clearly he also showed it to Sir Sayyid.

item.title: 121 UNKNOWN_TITLE
item.description: Source: Sir Syed Ahmed on the Present State of Indian Politics, Consisting of Speeches and Letters Reprinted from the “Pioneer” (Allahabad: The Pioneer Press, 1888), pp. 29-53. The text presented here has been slightly edited for classroom use, and its punctuation slightly improved, by FWP. Paragraph numbers, and some paragraph breaks, and annotations in square brackets have been added by FWP. The original spelling have been retained; all the footnotes are original.
